Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Rate of Disappearance

variables.-r_A: Rate of disappearance of species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Quantifies the rate at which species A is consumed per unit volume in a homogeneous system, used to analyze reaction kinetics in batch or flow reactors.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the rate of disappearance of A in a } 0.1 \, \text{m}^3 \text{ reactor where } N_A \text{ decreases from } 2 \, \text{mol} \text{ to } 1.8 \, \text{mol} \text{ in } 10 \, \text{s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Rate of Disappearance per Unit Weight

variables.-r_A': Rate of disappearance per unit weight (mol/(kg·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Measures the rate of consumption of species A per unit weight of catalyst in heterogeneous systems, critical for catalytic reactor design.

example.problem: \text{Find the rate of disappearance of A per unit weight in a reactor with } 5 \, \text{kg} \text{ catalyst where } N_A \text{ decreases by } 0.5 \, \text{mol} \text{ in } 20 \, \text{s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Rate of Disappearance per Unit Surface Area

variables.-r_A'': Rate of disappearance per unit surface area (mol/(m²·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the rate of consumption of species A per unit surface area, used in heterogeneous reactions where surface area is a limiting factor.

example.problem: \text{Determine the rate of disappearance of A per unit surface area for a } 2 \, \text{m}^2 \text{ catalyst where } N_A \text{ drops by } 0.1 \, \text{mol} \text{ in } 5 \, \text{s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: General Mole Balance Equation

variables.F_{j0}: Molar flow rate of species j into the system (mol/s)
variables.F_j: Molar flow rate of species j out of the system (mol/s)
variables.G_j: Rate of generation of species j (mol/s)
variables.N_j: Number of moles of species j (mol)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Balances the molar flow of species j, accounting for input, output, generation, and accumulation in any reactor system.

example.problem: \text{In a batch reactor (} F_{j0} = F_j = 0 \text{), if } G_j = 0.1 \, \text{mol/s} \text{ for species j, find } \frac{dN_j}{dt}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Integral Form of Mole Balance

variables.F_{j0}: Molar flow rate of species j into the system (mol/s)
variables.F_j: Molar flow rate of species j out of the system (mol/s)
variables.r_j: Rate of reaction for species j (mol/(m³·s))
variables.N_j: Number of moles of species j (mol)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Accounts for spatial variation of reaction rate across the reactor volume, used in non-uniform systems like plug flow reactors.

example.problem: \text{In a batch reactor (} F_{j0} = F_j = 0 \text{), if } r_j = 0.05 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)} \text{ in a } 2 \, \text{m}^3 \text{ reactor, find } \frac{dN_j}{dt}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Batch Reactor Design Equation

variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))
variables.N_A: Number of moles of species A (mol)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Relates the reaction rate to the rate of change of moles in a batch reactor, used to determine reaction time or reactor size.

example.problem: \text{In a } 0.5 \, \text{m}^3 \text{ batch reactor, if } r_A = -0.2 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find } \frac{dN_A}{dt}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Time for Conversion in Batch

variables.N_A: Moles of species A at time t (mol)
variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the time required to achieve a specific conversion in a batch reactor by integrating the inverse of the reaction rate.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction } r_A = -k C_A \text{ with } k = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, V = 1 \, \text{m}^3, \text{ find time to reduce } N_A \text{ from } 1 \, \text{mol} \text{ to } 0.5 \, \text{mol}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: CSTR Design Equation

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.F_A: Outlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Balances molar flow and reaction rate at steady state for a continuous stirred-tank reactor (CSTR), used to size the reactor.

example.problem: \text{For a CSTR with } F_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, F_A = 4 \, \text{mol/s}, r_A = -0.5 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find the required volume.}

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Volume for CSTR

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.F_A: Outlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Rearranged CSTR design equation to directly calculate the reactor volume required for a given conversion.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the CSTR volume for } F_{A0} = 20 \, \text{mol/s}, F_A = 5 \, \text{mol/s}, -r_A = 0.3 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: PFR Differential Equation

variables.F_j: Molar flow rate of species j (mol/s)
variables.r_j: Rate of reaction for species j (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Describes the change in molar flow rate with respect to reactor volume in a plug flow reactor (PFR), used for reactor sizing.

example.problem: \text{For a PFR with } r_j = -0.4 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find the change in } F_j \text{ over } 2 \, \text{m}^3.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: PFR Integral Equation

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.F_A: Outlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Integrates the inverse reaction rate to determine the volume of a plug flow reactor needed for a specific conversion.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction } r_A = -k C_A, k = 0.2 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, F_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, \text{ find } V \text{ for } F_A = 5 \, \text{mol/s}, v_0 = 10 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: PBR Design Equation

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.F_A: Outlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.r_A': Rate of reaction per unit weight of catalyst (mol/(kg·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Determines the catalyst weight required for a packed bed reactor (PBR) to achieve a desired conversion.

example.problem: \text{For a PBR with } r_A' = -0.01 \, \text{mol/(kg·s)}, F_{A0} = 8 \, \text{mol/s}, F_A = 2 \, \text{mol/s}, \text{ find } W.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Conversion Definition Batch
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the fractional conversion of reactant A in a batch reactor, indicating the extent of reaction.

example.problem: \text{Calculate the conversion if } N_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol} \text{ and } N_A = 3 \, \text{mol} \text{ remain in a batch reactor.}

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Moles in Terms of Conversion

variables.N_A: Moles of species A at time t (mol)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the remaining moles of reactant A in a batch reactor as a function of conversion.

example.problem: \text{Find } N_A \text{ for } N_{A0} = 5 \, \text{mol} \text{ and } X_A = 0.4 \text{ in a batch reactor.}

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Batch Time in Terms of Conversion

variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the time required to achieve a specific conversion in a batch reactor, integrating with respect to conversion.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction } r_A = -k C_A, k = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, V = 1 \, \text{m}^3, N_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol}, \text{ find } t \text{ for } X_A = 0.5.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Conversion Definition Flow

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.F_A: Outlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the fractional conversion of reactant A in flow reactors like CSTR or PFR, based on molar flow rates.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } X_A \text{ for a flow reactor with } F_{A0} = 15 \, \text{mol/s}, F_A = 6 \, \text{mol/s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Flow Rate in Terms of Conversion

variables.F_A: Outlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the outlet molar flow rate of reactant A in terms of conversion in a flow reactor.

example.problem: \text{Find } F_A \text{ for } F_{A0} = 12 \, \text{mol/s}, X_A = 0.25 \text{ in a flow reactor.}

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: CSTR Volume in Terms of Conversion

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the volume of a CSTR needed to achieve a specific conversion, derived from the steady-state mole balance.

example.problem: \text{For a CSTR with } F_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, X_A = 0.4, -r_A = 0.2 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find } V.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: PFR Volume in Terms of Conversion

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Determines the volume of a plug flow reactor required to achieve a specific conversion by integrating with respect to conversion.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction } r_A = -k C_A, k = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, F_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, v_0 = 10 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, \text{ find } V \text{ for } X_A = 0.5.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: PBR Weight in Terms of Conversion

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.r_A': Rate of reaction per unit weight of catalyst (mol/(kg·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the catalyst weight needed in a packed bed reactor to achieve a specific conversion.

example.problem: \text{For a PBR with } r_A' = -0.02 \, \text{mol/(kg·s)}, F_{A0} = 5 \, \text{mol/s}, \text{ find } W \text{ for } X_A = 0.6.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Relative Rates

variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))
variables.r_B: Rate of reaction for species B (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Relates the reaction rates of species A and B based on their stoichiometric coefficients in the reaction aA + bB → products.

example.problem: \text{For the reaction } 2A + 3B \to C, \text{ if } r_A = -0.4 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find } r_B.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Power Law Rate

variables.-r_A: Rate of disappearance of species A (mol/(m³·s))
variables.k: Rate constant (units vary with reaction order)
variables.\\alpha: Reaction order with respect to A (dimensionless)
variables.\\beta: Reaction order with respect to B (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the reaction rate as a function of reactant concentrations and reaction orders, used to model reaction kinetics.

example.problem: \text{For } -r_A = k C_A^2 C_B, k = 0.01 \, \text{m}^6/(\text{mol}^2\cdot\text{s)}, C_A = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_B = 3 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } -r_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Arrhenius Equation

variables.k: Rate constant (units vary with reaction order)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Describes the temperature dependence of the reaction rate constant, used to predict reaction rates at different temperatures.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } k \text{ for } A = 10^5 \, \text{s}^{-1}, E_A = 50 \, \text{kJ/mol}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, R = 8.314 \, \text{J/(mol·K)}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Concentration in Constant Density
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Relates the concentration of reactant A to its initial concentration and conversion in constant-density systems.

example.problem: \text{Find } C_A \text{ for } C_{A0} = 1.5 \, \text{mol/m}^3, X_A = 0.2 \text{ in a constant-density system.}

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Levenspiel Plot Function

variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.-r_A: Rate of disappearance of species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Used to graphically determine reactor volume by plotting the inverse rate versus conversion for flow reactors.

example.problem: \text{For } -r_A = k C_A, k = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, F_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, v_0 = 10 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, \text{ find } \frac{F_{A0}}{-r_A} \text{ at } X_A = 0.5.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Space Time
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Represents the time required to process one reactor volume of feed at inlet conditions, used in flow reactor analysis.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } \tau \text{ for a reactor with } V = 5 \, \text{m}^3, v_0 = 0.2 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Space Velocity
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: The reciprocal of space time, indicating the number of reactor volumes processed per unit time.

example.problem: \text{Find } SV \text{ for } V = 4 \, \text{m}^3, v_0 = 0.5 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: LHSV
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Measures the liquid volumetric flow rate per unit reactor volume per hour, used in liquid-phase reactor design.

example.problem: \text{Calculate } LHSV \text{ for } v_{liq} = 2 \, \text{m}^3/\text{h}, V = 10 \, \text{m}^3.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: GHSV

variables.v_{STP}: Gas volumetric flow rate at standard temperature and pressure (m³/h)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Measures the gas volumetric flow rate at STP per unit reactor volume per hour, used in gas-phase reactor design.

example.problem: \text{Find } GHSV \text{ for } v_{STP} = 100 \, \text{m}^3/\text{h}, V = 20 \, \text{m}^3.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Stoichiometric Relation

variables.r_A: Rate of reaction for species A (mol/(m³·s))
variables.r_B: Rate of reaction for species B (mol/(m³·s))
variables.r_C: Rate of formation of species C (mol/(m³·s))
variables.r_D: Rate of formation of species D (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Relates the rates of consumption and formation of species in the reaction aA + bB → cC + dD based on stoichiometry.

example.problem: \text{For } A + 2B \to 3C, \text{ if } r_A = -0.5 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find } r_C.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Moles Consumed Batch

variables.N_A: Moles of species A at time t (mol)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the remaining moles of the limiting reactant A in a batch reactor based on conversion.

example.problem: \text{In a batch reactor, if } N_{A0} = 8 \, \text{mol} \text{ and } X_A = 0.3, \text{ find } N_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Moles B Consumed Batch

variables.N_B: Moles of species B at time t (mol)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Determines the moles of reactant B remaining in a batch reactor, accounting for its stoichiometric consumption relative to A.

example.problem: \text{For } 2A + B \to C, \text{ with } N_{A0} = 4 \, \text{mol}, N_{B0} = 3 \, \text{mol}, X_A = 0.5, \text{ find } N_B.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Moles C Produced Batch

variables.N_C: Moles of species C at time t (mol)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the moles of product C produced in a batch reactor based on the conversion of limiting reactant A.

example.problem: \text{For } A + B \to 2C, \text{ with } N_{A0} = 5 \, \text{mol}, N_{C0} = 0 \, \text{mol}, X_A = 0.4, \text{ find } N_C.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Theta Definition

variables.\\theta_i: Initial molar ratio of species i to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the initial molar ratio of species i to the limiting reactant A, used in stoichiometric calculations.

example.problem: \text{For a batch reactor with } N_{B0} = 6 \, \text{mol}, N_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol}, \text{ calculate } \theta_B.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Concentration with Theta

variables.\\theta_B: Initial molar ratio of B to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the concentration of reactant B in a constant-density system, accounting for its consumption relative to A.

example.problem: \text{For } 2A + B \to C, \text{ with } C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \theta_B = 2, X_A = 0.3, \text{ find } C_B.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Flow Rate Consumed

variables.F_B: Molar flow rate of species B (mol/s)
variables.F_{A0}: Inlet molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.\\theta_B: Initial molar ratio of B to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the molar flow rate of reactant B in a flow reactor, accounting for its consumption based on stoichiometry.

example.problem: \text{For } A + 2B \to C, \text{ with } F_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, \theta_B = 3, X_A = 0.4, \text{ find } F_B.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: First Order Batch Time
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the time required for a first-order reaction in a batch reactor to achieve a specific conversion, assuming constant density.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction with } k = 0.02 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \text{ find } t \text{ for } X_A = 0.5.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: First Order Batch Conversion
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the conversion achieved in a first-order batch reaction as a function of time and rate constant.

example.problem: \text{For } k = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, t = 5 \, \text{s}, \text{ find } X_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Second Order Batch Time
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the time required for a second-order reaction in a batch reactor to achieve a specific conversion.

example.problem: \text{For } C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, k = 0.01 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, X_A = 0.5, \text{ find } t.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Second Order Batch Conversion
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the conversion for a second-order reaction in a batch reactor as a function of time, rate constant, and initial concentration.

example.problem: \text{For } t = 100 \, \text{s}, k = 0.02 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } X_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Bimolecular Second Order Time
Chemical Reaction Engineering.formula: t = \frac{1}{C_{A0} k (\theta_B - Z)} \ln \left( \frac{\theta_B - Z X_A}{1 - X_A} \right) - \ln \theta_B

variables.\\theta_B: Initial molar ratio of B to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the time for a bimolecular second-order reaction aA + bB → products in a batch reactor.

example.problem: \text{For } A + B \to C, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, k = 0.05 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, \theta_B = 2, Z = 1, X_A = 0.4, \text{ find } t.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: First Order CSTR Conversion
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the conversion for a first-order reaction in a CSTR, derived from the design equation.

example.problem: \text{For } \tau = 50 \, \text{s}, k = 0.02 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \text{ find } X_A \text{ in a CSTR.}

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Second Order CSTR Volume
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Determines the volume of a CSTR for a second-order reaction to achieve a specific conversion.

example.problem: \text{For } v_0 = 0.1 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, X_A = 0.6, k = 0.01 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } V.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Second Order CSTR Conversion Quadratic
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Solves for conversion in a second-order CSTR reaction by solving the quadratic equation derived from the design equation.

example.problem: \text{For } C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \tau = 100 \, \text{s}, k = 0.02 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, \text{ find } X_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: First Order PFR Conversion
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the conversion for a first-order reaction in a plug flow reactor, derived from the PFR design equation.

example.problem: \text{For } \tau = 20 \, \text{s}, k = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \text{ find } X_A \text{ in a PFR.}

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Second Order PFR Volume
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Determines the volume of a PFR for a second-order reaction to achieve a specific conversion.

example.problem: \text{For } v_0 = 0.2 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, k = 0.01 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, X_A = 0.5, \text{ find } V.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Bimolecular Second Order PFR Volume
Chemical Reaction Engineering.formula: V = \frac{v_0}{k C_{A0} (\theta_B - Z)} \ln \left( \frac{\theta_B - Z X_A}{1 - X_A} \right) - \ln \theta_B

variables.\\theta_B: Initial molar ratio of B to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the volume of a PFR for a bimolecular second-order reaction aA + bB → products.

example.problem: \text{For } A + B \to C, v_0 = 0.1 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, k = 0.05 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \theta_B = 2, Z = 1, X_A = 0.4, \text{ find } V.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Molar Flow Rate of A

variables.F_A: Molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)
variables.F_{A0}: Initial molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the molar flow rate of reactant A in a flow reactor as a function of its initial flow rate and conversion.

example.problem: \text{Find } F_A \text{ for } F_{A0} = 20 \, \text{mol/s}, X_A = 0.3.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Molar Flow Rate of B

variables.F_B: Molar flow rate of species B (mol/s)
variables.F_{B0}: Initial molar flow rate of species B (mol/s)
variables.F_{A0}: Initial molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the molar flow rate of reactant B in a flow reactor, accounting for its consumption relative to A.

example.problem: \text{For } 2A + B \to C, \text{ with } F_{A0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, F_{B0} = 8 \, \text{mol/s}, X_A = 0.4, \text{ find } F_B.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Molar Flow Rate of C

variables.F_C: Molar flow rate of species C (mol/s)
variables.F_{C0}: Initial molar flow rate of species C (mol/s)
variables.F_{A0}: Initial molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Determines the molar flow rate of product C in a flow reactor based on the conversion of limiting reactant A.

example.problem: \text{For } A + B \to 2C, \text{ with } F_{A0} = 5 \, \text{mol/s}, F_{C0} = 0 \, \text{mol/s}, X_A = 0.6, \text{ find } F_C.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Molar Flow Rate of D

variables.F_D: Molar flow rate of species D (mol/s)
variables.F_{D0}: Initial molar flow rate of species D (mol/s)
variables.F_{A0}: Initial molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the molar flow rate of product D in a flow reactor based on the conversion of limiting reactant A.

example.problem: \text{For } 2A + B \to 3D, \text{ with } F_{A0} = 4 \, \text{mol/s}, F_{D0} = 1 \, \text{mol/s}, X_A = 0.5, \text{ find } F_D.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Total Molar Flow Rate

variables.\\delta: Change in number of moles per mole of A reacted (dimensionless)
variables.F_{A0}: Initial molar flow rate of species A (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Accounts for the change in total molar flow rate in a flow reactor due to the stoichiometric effect of the reaction on the number of moles.

example.problem: \text{For the reaction } A \to 2B, \text{ with } F_{T0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, F_{A0} = 5 \, \text{mol/s}, X_A = 0.4, \delta = 2 - 1 = 1, \text{ find } F_T.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Change in Number of Moles Delta

variables.\\delta: Change in number of moles per mole of A reacted (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the net change in the number of moles per mole of limiting reactant A reacted, used to adjust molar flow rates in gas-phase reactions.

example.problem: \text{For the reaction } 2A + 3B \to 4C + D, \text{ calculate } \delta.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Volumetric Flow Rate for Gases
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the volumetric flow rate for gaseous mixtures, accounting for changes in pressure, molar flow, and temperature.

example.problem: \text{For } \dot{V}_0 = 0.1 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}, P = 90000 \, \text{Pa}, F_T = 12 \, \text{mol/s}, F_{T0} = 10 \, \text{mol/s}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, T_0 = 298 \, \text{K}, \text{ find } \dot{V}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Concentration of A for Variable Density
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the concentration of reactant A in systems with variable density, accounting for conversion, expansion, temperature, and pressure changes.

example.problem: \text{For } C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, X_A = 0.3, \epsilon = 1, T_0 = 298 \, \text{K}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, P = 90000 \, \text{Pa}, P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}, \text{ find } C_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Concentration of B for Variable Density

variables.\\theta_B: Initial molar ratio of B to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the concentration of reactant B in variable density systems, considering stoichiometric consumption and system changes.

example.problem: \text{For } A + 2B \to C, \text{ with } C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \theta_B = 2, X_A = 0.4, \epsilon = 0.5, T_0 = 298 \, \text{K}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, P = 95000 \, \text{Pa}, P_0 = 100000 \, \text{Pa}, \text{ find } C_B.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Concentration of C for Variable Density

variables.\\theta_C: Initial molar ratio of C to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the concentration of product C in variable density systems, accounting for its production and system changes.

example.problem: \text{For } 2A \to 3C, \text{ with } C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \theta_C = 0, X_A = 0.5, \epsilon = 0.5, T_0 = 298 \, \text{K}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, P = 95000 \, \text{Pa}, P_0 = 100000 \, \text{Pa}, \text{ find } C_C.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Concentration of D for Variable Density

variables.\\theta_D: Initial molar ratio of D to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the concentration of product D in variable density systems, considering its production and changes in system conditions.

example.problem: \text{For } A + B \to 2D, \text{ with } C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \theta_D = 0, X_A = 0.3, \epsilon = 0.2, T_0 = 298 \, \text{K}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, P = 90000 \, \text{Pa}, P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}, \text{ find } C_D.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Concentration of Inert for Variable Density

variables.\\theta_I: Initial molar ratio of inert to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the concentration of an inert species in a variable density system, affected by changes in volume, temperature, and pressure.

example.problem: \text{For a system with } C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \theta_I = 3, X_A = 0.4, \epsilon = 0.5, T_0 = 298 \, \text{K}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, P = 95000 \, \text{Pa}, P_0 = 100000 \, \text{Pa}, \text{ find } C_I.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Volumetric Flow Rate Expression
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Simplified expression for the volumetric flow rate in variable density systems, incorporating expansion due to reaction.

example.problem: \text{For } \dot{V}_0 = 0.2 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, \epsilon = 1, X_A = 0.3, T = 300 \, \text{K}, T_0 = 298 \, \text{K}, P = 90000 \, \text{Pa}, P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}, \text{ find } \dot{V}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Instantaneous Selectivity

variables.S_{D/U}: Instantaneous selectivity of desired product D over undesired product U (dimensionless)
variables.r_D: Rate of formation of desired product D (mol/(m³·s))
variables.r_U: Rate of formation of undesired product U (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Measures the ratio of the formation rate of the desired product to the undesired product at a specific point in the reaction.

example.problem: \text{For parallel reactions producing } D \text{ and } U, \text{ if } r_D = 0.8 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, r_U = 0.2 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find } S_{D/U}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Overall Selectivity Batch

variables.\\tilde{S}_{D/U}: Overall selectivity of desired product D over undesired product U (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the overall selectivity in a batch reactor by comparing the total moles of desired product to undesired product.

example.problem: \text{In a batch reactor, if } N_D = 6 \, \text{mol}, N_U = 2 \, \text{mol}, \text{ find } \tilde{S}_{D/U}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Overall Selectivity Flow

variables.\\tilde{S}_{D/U}: Overall selectivity of desired product D over undesired product U (dimensionless)
variables.F_D: Molar flow rate of desired product D (mol/s)
variables.F_U: Molar flow rate of undesired product U (mol/s)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the overall selectivity in a flow reactor by comparing the molar flow rates of desired and undesired products.

example.problem: \text{In a flow reactor, if } F_D = 5 \, \text{mol/s}, F_U = 1 \, \text{mol/s}, \text{ find } \tilde{S}_{D/U}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Net Rate for Species i

variables.r_{i,Net}: Net rate of formation for species i (mol/(m³·s))
variables.\\nu_{ij}: Stoichiometric coefficient of species i in reaction j (dimensionless, negative for reactants)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Sums the contributions of all reactions to the net rate of formation or consumption of species i in a multiple-reaction system.

example.problem: \text{For two reactions: } A \to B \text{ with } r_1 = 0.3 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ and } B \to C \text{ with } r_2 = 0.1 \, \text{mol/(m}^3\cdot\text{s)}, \text{ find } r_{B,Net}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Selectivity for Parallel Reactions

variables.S_{D/U}: Instantaneous selectivity of desired product D over undesired product U (dimensionless)
variables.k_D: Rate constant for desired reaction (units vary)
variables.k_U: Rate constant for undesired reaction (units vary)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates selectivity for parallel reactions producing desired and undesired products, depending on reactant concentration and reaction orders.

example.problem: \text{For parallel reactions } A \to D \text{ (first order, } k_D = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}) \text{ and } A \to U \text{ (second order, } k_U = 0.05 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}), \text{ with } C_A = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } S_{D/U}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Selectivity with Temperature Dependence

variables.S_{D/U}: Instantaneous selectivity of desired product D over undesired product U (dimensionless)
variables.k_D: Pre-exponential factor for desired reaction (units vary)
variables.k_U: Pre-exponential factor for undesired reaction (units vary)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses selectivity for parallel reactions when concentration effects cancel out, highlighting temperature dependence through activation energies.

example.problem: \text{For } k_D = k_U = 10^5 \, \text{s}^{-1}, E_D = 50 \, \text{kJ/mol}, E_U = 60 \, \text{kJ/mol}, T = 300 \, \text{K}, R = 8.314 \, \text{J/(mol·K)}, \text{ find } S_{D/U}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Selectivity for Bimolecular Parallel

variables.S_{D/U}: Instantaneous selectivity of desired product D over undesired product U (dimensionless)
variables.k_D: Rate constant for desired reaction (units vary)
variables.k_U: Rate constant for undesired reaction (units vary)
variables.\\alpha_1: Order with respect to A for desired reaction (dimensionless)
variables.\\alpha_2: Order with respect to A for undesired reaction (dimensionless)
variables.\\beta_1: Order with respect to B for desired reaction (dimensionless)
variables.\\beta_2: Order with respect to B for undesired reaction (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates selectivity for parallel bimolecular reactions, accounting for different reaction orders with respect to two reactants.

example.problem: \text{For parallel reactions } A + B \to D \text{ (} k_D = 0.02 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, \alpha_1 = 1, \beta_1 = 1 \text{) and } A \to U \text{ (} k_U = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \alpha_2 = 1, \beta_2 = 0 \text{), with } C_A = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_B = 3 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } S_{D/U}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Three-Point Differentiation Initial

variables.\\left( \\frac{dC_A}{dt} \\right)_{t_0}: Rate of change of concentration of A at initial time (mol/(m³·s))
variables.C_{A,0}: Concentration of A at initial time (mol/m³)
variables.C_{A1}: Concentration of A at first time step (mol/m³)
variables.C_{A2}: Concentration of A at second time step (mol/m³)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Approximates the initial rate of change of concentration using a three-point finite difference method for the first data point.

example.problem: \text{For } C_{A,0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_{A1} = 0.95 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_{A2} = 0.88 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \Delta t = 2 \, \text{s}, \text{ find } \left( \frac{dC_A}{dt} \right)_{t_0}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Three-Point Differentiation Interior

variables.\\left( \\frac{dC_A}{dt} \\right)_{t_i}: Rate of change of concentration of A at time t_i (mol/(m³·s))
variables.C_{A,i+1}: Concentration of A at next time step (mol/m³)
variables.C_{A,i-1}: Concentration of A at previous time step (mol/m³)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Approximates the rate of change of concentration at an interior point using a centered three-point finite difference method.

example.problem: \text{For } C_{A,i-1} = 1.1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_{A,i+1} = 0.9 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \Delta t = 1 \, \text{s}, \text{ find } \left( \frac{dC_A}{dt} \right)_{t_i}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Three-Point Differentiation Final

variables.\\left( \\frac{dC_A}{dt} \\right)_{t_n}: Rate of change of concentration of A at final time (mol/(m³·s))
variables.C_{A,n-2}: Concentration of A two time steps before final (mol/m³)
variables.C_{A,n-1}: Concentration of A one time step before final (mol/m³)
variables.C_{A,n}: Concentration of A at final time (mol/m³)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Approximates the rate of change of concentration at the final data point using a three-point finite difference method.

example.problem: \text{For } C_{A,n-2} = 0.7 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_{A,n-1} = 0.65 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_{A,n} = 0.6 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \Delta t = 2 \, \text{s}, \text{ find } \left( \frac{dC_A}{dt} \right)_{t_n}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Half-Life General
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the half-life for an nth-order reaction (n ≠ 1), representing the time for half of the reactant to be consumed.

example.problem: \text{For a second-order reaction (} n = 2 \text{) with } k = 0.01 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } t_{1/2}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Half-Life First Order
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the half-life for a first-order reaction, independent of initial concentration.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction with } k = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \text{ find } t_{1/2}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Log Half-Life
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Linearized form of the half-life equation used to determine reaction order by plotting ln(t_{1/2}) versus ln(C_{A0}).

example.problem: \text{For a second-order reaction (} n = 2 \text{) with } k = 0.01 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{mol·s)}, C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } \ln t_{1/2}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Time for Maximum Intermediate in Series

variables.k_1: Rate constant for reaction A to B (s^{-1})
variables.k_2: Rate constant for reaction B to C (s^{-1})

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Determines the time at which the concentration of intermediate B is maximized in a consecutive reaction A → B → C.

example.problem: \text{For } A \to B \to C, \text{ with } k_1 = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, k_2 = 0.2 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \text{ find } t \text{ for maximum } [B].

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Gibbs Free Energy Change
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Standard Gibbs free energy change for the reaction CH4 + CO2 → 2CO + 2H2 at 373 K, indicating non-spontaneity at this temperature.

example.problem: \text{Determine if the reaction } CH_4 + CO_2 \to 2CO + 2H_2 \text{ is spontaneous at } 373 \, \text{K}, \text{ given } \Delta G^0 = 151 \, \text{kJ/mol}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Gibbs Free Energy Change
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Standard Gibbs free energy change for the reaction CH4 + CO2 → 2CO + 2H2 at 973 K, indicating spontaneity at this temperature.

example.problem: \text{Determine if the reaction } CH_4 + CO_2 \to 2CO + 2H_2 \text{ is spontaneous at } 973 \, \text{K}, \text{ given } \Delta G^0 = -16 \, \text{kJ/mol}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Net Rate of Adsorption
Chemical Reaction Engineering.formula: r_{AD} = k_A P_A C_V - k_{-A} C_{A.S}

variables.r_{AD}: Net rate of adsorption (mol/(g cat · s))
variables.k_A: Adsorption rate constant (mol/(g cat · s · atm))
variables.C_{A.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by A (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the net rate of adsorption of species A onto catalyst sites, balancing adsorption and desorption processes.

example.problem: \text{For } k_A = 0.01 \, \text{mol/(g cat · s · atm)}, P_A = 2 \, \text{atm}, C_V = 0.1 \, \text{mol/g cat}, k_{-A} = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A.S} = 0.02 \, \text{mol/g cat}, \text{ find } r_{AD}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Adsorption Equilibrium Constant

variables.k_A: Adsorption rate constant (mol/(g cat · s · atm))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the equilibrium constant for the adsorption of species A, as the ratio of adsorption to desorption rate constants.

example.problem: \text{For } k_A = 0.02 \, \text{mol/(g cat · s · atm)}, k_{-A} = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \text{ find } K_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Net Rate of Adsorption in Terms of Equilibrium

variables.r_{AD}: Net rate of adsorption (mol/(g cat · s))
variables.k_A: Adsorption rate constant (mol/(g cat · s · atm))
variables.C_{A.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by A (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Expresses the net adsorption rate using the equilibrium constant, useful for simplifying catalytic reaction models.

example.problem: \text{For } k_A = 0.01 \, \text{mol/(g cat · s · atm)}, P_A = 1.5 \, \text{atm}, C_V = 0.2 \, \text{mol/g cat}, C_{A.S} = 0.03 \, \text{mol/g cat}, K_A = 0.25 \, \text{atm}^{-1}, \text{ find } r_{AD}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Net Rate of Surface Reaction Single Site

variables.r_S: Net rate of surface reaction (mol/(g cat · s))
variables.C_{A.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by A (mol/g cat)
variables.C_{B.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by B (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the net rate of a surface reaction for a single-site mechanism, balancing forward and reverse reactions.

example.problem: \text{For } k_S = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A.S} = 0.1 \, \text{mol/g cat}, C_{B.S} = 0.02 \, \text{mol/g cat}, K_S = 2, \text{ find } r_S.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Surface Equilibrium Constant
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the equilibrium constant for a surface reaction as the ratio of forward to reverse rate constants.

example.problem: \text{For } k_S = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, k_{-S} = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, \text{ find } K_S.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Net Rate of Surface Reaction Dual Site

variables.r_S: Net rate of surface reaction (mol/(g cat · s))
variables.k_S: Surface reaction rate constant (g cat/mol · s)
variables.C_{A.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by A (mol/g cat)
variables.C_{B.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by B (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the net rate of a surface reaction requiring two active sites, used in dual-site catalytic mechanisms.

example.problem: \text{For } k_S = 0.02 \, \text{g cat/(mol · s)}, C_{A.S} = 0.1 \, \text{mol/g cat}, C_V = 0.2 \, \text{mol/g cat}, C_{B.S} = 0.03 \, \text{mol/g cat}, K_S = 1.5, \text{ find } r_S.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Net Rate of Surface Reaction Eley-Rideal

variables.r_S: Net rate of surface reaction (mol/(g cat · s))
variables.k_S: Surface reaction rate constant (mol/(g cat · s · atm))
variables.C_{A.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by A (mol/g cat)
variables.C_{C.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by C (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the net rate of a surface reaction following the Eley-Rideal mechanism, where a gas-phase species reacts with an adsorbed species.

example.problem: \text{For } k_S = 0.01 \, \text{mol/(g cat · s · atm)}, P_B = 1.5 \, \text{atm}, C_{A.S} = 0.1 \, \text{mol/g cat}, C_{C.S} = 0.02 \, \text{mol/g cat}, K_S = 2 \, \text{atm}^{-1}, \text{ find } r_S.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Net Rate of Desorption

variables.r_D: Net rate of desorption (mol/(g cat · s))
variables.C_{C.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by C (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the net rate of desorption of species C from catalyst sites, balancing desorption and adsorption processes.

example.problem: \text{For } k_D = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{C.S} = 0.03 \, \text{mol/g cat}, P_C = 1 \, \text{atm}, C_V = 0.2 \, \text{mol/g cat}, K_{D,C} = 0.5 \, \text{atm}^{-1}, \text{ find } r_D.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Desorption Equilibrium Constant

variables.k_{-D}: Reverse desorption rate constant (mol/(g cat · s · atm))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the equilibrium constant for the desorption of species C as the ratio of desorption to adsorption rate constants.

example.problem: \text{For } k_D = 0.1 \, \text{s}^{-1}, k_{-D} = 0.2 \, \text{mol/(g cat · s · atm)}, \text{ find } K_{D,C}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Adsorption Equilibrium from Desorption
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Relates the adsorption equilibrium constant to the desorption equilibrium constant for species C, used in catalytic reaction models.

example.problem: \text{For } K_{D,C} = 0.4 \, \text{atm}^{-1}, \text{ find } K_C.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Site Balance

variables.C_T: Total concentration of active sites (mol/g cat)
variables.C_{A.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by A (mol/g cat)
variables.C_{B.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by B (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Balances the total number of catalyst sites, summing vacant and occupied sites, essential for catalytic reaction kinetics.

example.problem: \text{For } C_V = 0.3 \, \text{mol/g cat}, C_{A.S} = 0.2 \, \text{mol/g cat}, C_{B.S} = 0.1 \, \text{mol/g cat}, \text{ find } C_T.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Occupied Site Concentration

variables.C_{C.S}: Concentration of sites occupied by C (mol/g cat)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the concentration of sites occupied by species C under equilibrium assumptions in catalytic reactions.

example.problem: \text{For } K_B = 0.5 \, \text{atm}^{-1}, P_B = 1 \, \text{atm}, P_P = 0.5 \, \text{atm}, C_V = 0.2 \, \text{mol/g cat}, K_S = 2, \text{ find } C_{C.S}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Pressure Drop in Packed Bed
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the pressure drop across a packed bed reactor using the Ergun equation, accounting for friction and inertial losses.

example.problem: \text{For } G = 2 \, \text{kg/(m}^2\cdot\text{s)}, \rho = 1.2 \, \text{kg/m}^3, D_p = 0.001 \, \text{m}, \phi = 0.4, \mu = 1.8 \times 10^{-5} \, \text{Pa·s}, \text{ find } \frac{dP}{dz}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Gas Density Relation
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Relates gas density to volumetric flow rates, derived from mass continuity in a flow system.

example.problem: \text{For } \rho_0 = 1.2 \, \text{kg/m}^3, \dot{V}_0 = 0.1 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, \dot{V} = 0.12 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, \text{ find } \rho.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Beta Zero
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the constant parameter in the Ergun equation for pressure drop in a packed bed under initial conditions.

example.problem: \text{For } G = 1.5 \, \text{kg/(m}^2\cdot\text{s)}, \rho_0 = 1.2 \, \text{kg/m}^3, D_p = 0.002 \, \text{m}, \phi = 0.45, \mu = 2 \times 10^{-5} \, \text{Pa·s}, \text{ find } \beta_0.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Pressure Drop Simplified
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Simplifies the pressure drop calculation in a packed bed by relating it to the volumetric flow rate ratio.

example.problem: \text{For } \beta_0 = 10000 \, \text{Pa/m}, \dot{V} = 0.15 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, \dot{V}_0 = 0.1 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, \text{ find } \frac{dP}{dz}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Alpha Definition
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the pressure drop parameter alpha for packed bed reactors, relating pressure drop to catalyst weight.

example.problem: \text{For } \beta_0 = 5000 \, \text{Pa/m}, P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}, \phi = 0.4, A = 0.5 \, \text{m}^2, \rho_c = 1500 \, \text{kg/m}^3, \text{ find } \alpha.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Pressure in Terms of Alpha
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the pressure in a packed bed reactor as a function of catalyst weight, assuming isothermal conditions and no change in moles.

example.problem: \text{For } P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}, \alpha = 0.0002 \, \text{kg}^{-1}, W = 1000 \, \text{kg}, \text{ find } P.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Conversion with Pressure Drop First Order
Chemical Reaction Engineering.formula: X_A = 1 - e^{- \frac{2k C_{A0}}{\beta_0 \dot{V}_0} \left( P_0 - \sqrt{P_0^2 - \alpha W P_0} \right)}
Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the conversion of reactant A in a packed bed reactor for a first-order reaction, accounting for pressure drop using the Ergun equation and catalyst weight.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction with } k = 0.01 \, \text{m}^3/(\text{kg cat · s)}, C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \beta_0 = 10000 \, \text{Pa/m}, \dot{V}_0 = 0.1 \, \text{m}^3/\text{s}, P_0 = 101325 \, \text{Pa}, \alpha = 0.0002 \, \text{kg}^{-1}, W = 500 \, \text{kg}, \text{ find } X_A.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Moles Consumed Batch

variables.N_A: Moles of species A at time t (mol)
variables.r_A: Rate of reaction of species A (mol/(m³·s))

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Calculates the moles of reactant A consumed in a batch reactor over time, based on the reaction rate and reactor volume.

example.problem: \text{For a first-order reaction } r_A = k C_A \text{ with } k = 0.05 \, \text{s}^{-1}, C_{A0} = 1 \, \text{mol/m}^3, V = 0.2 \, \text{m}^3, \text{ find moles consumed after } t = 10 \, \text{s}.

Chemical Reaction Engineering.name: Theta Definition

variables.\\theta_i: Initial molar ratio of species i to A (dimensionless)

Chemical Reaction Engineering.description: Defines the initial molar ratio of species i to the limiting reactant A, used to express concentrations in reaction systems relative to A.

example.problem: \text{For a reaction system with } C_{B0} = 3 \, \text{mol/m}^3, C_{A0} = 2 \, \text{mol/m}^3, \text{ find } \theta_B.
